questions.question: In the figure, line <math><mi>p</mi></math> is parallel to line <math><mi>q</mi></math>. If the measure of angle 1 is <math><mn>115</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the measure of angle 2?
questions.explanation: When two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, corresponding angles are congruent. Angle 1 and angle 2 are corresponding angles, so they have the same measure. Therefore, angle 2 also measures <math><mn>115</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the angle relationships formed by parallel lines and a transversal: corresponding angles are congruent, alternate interior angles are congruent, and same-side interior angles are supplementary.

questions.question: If <math><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: First, distribute: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Simplify: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Subtract <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Subtract 5: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Divide by 2: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving linear equations, always simplify both sides by distributing and combining like terms before isolating the variable.

questions.question: What are the solutions to the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Rewrite the equation: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Taking the square root of both sides gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For equations of the form <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi></math>, remember to consider both the positive and negative square roots.

questions.question: In triangle <math><mi>P</mi><mi>Q</mi><mi>R</mi></math>, the measure of angle <math><mi>P</mi></math> is <math><mn>47</mn><mo>°</mo></math> and the measure of angle <math><mi>Q</mi></math> is <math><mn>78</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the measure, in degrees, of angle <math><mi>R</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The sum of interior angles in a triangle is <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. Therefore, <math><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>47</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>78</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>55</mn></math> degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The triangle angle sum theorem is a fundamental tool. Always check that your three found angles sum to 180 degrees.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><pattern id='grid' width='20' height='20' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse'><path d='M 20 0 L 0 0 0 20' fill='none' stroke='lightgray' stroke-width='0.5'/></pattern></defs><rect width='400' height='300' fill='url(#grid)'/><line x1='200' y1='0' x2='200' y2='300' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='0' y1='150' x2='400' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='380' y='165' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>x</text><text x='210' y='15' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>y</text><line x1='160' y1='250' x2='240' y2='10' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2'/><text x='170' y='60' font-size='12' fill='blue'>y = 3x + 1</text><line x1='180' y1='290' x2='260' y2='50' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><text x='270' y='100' font-size='12' fill='red'>y = 3x - 4</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Graph of two parallel lines in the xy-plane. The solid blue line represents y = 3x + 1, and the dashed red line represents y = 3x - 4. Both lines have a positive slope and do not intersect.
questions.question: The graph of the system of equations <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math> is shown. How many solutions does the system have?
questions.explanation: Identify the slope and y-intercept of each line. The first equation is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, so the slope is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn></math> and the y-intercept is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>1</mn></math>. The second equation is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math>, so the slope is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn></math> and the y-intercept is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Since both lines have the same slope (<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn></math>) but different y-intercepts, they are parallel lines. Parallel lines never intersect, meaning there is no point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></math> that satisfies both equations simultaneously. Therefore, the system has zero solutions.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='200' y1='0' x2='200' y2='300' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='0' y1='150' x2='400' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='160' y1='250' x2='240' y2='10' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='180' y1='290' x2='260' y2='50' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><path d='M 195 145 L 205 115 L 210 120 L 200 150' fill='blue' /><path d='M 215 185 L 225 155 L 230 160 L 220 190' fill='red' /><text x='270' y='150' font-size='14' fill='black' font-weight='bold'>Same Slope (m=3)</text><text x='270' y='170' font-size='14' fill='black'>Parallel = No Solutions</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart highlights that the lines are parallel by marking them with arrows indicating the same direction. Text annotations confirm that because the slopes are equal (m=3), there are no solutions.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check the slopes and y-intercepts: Same slope + different intercepts = Parallel (0 solutions). Same slope + same intercepts = Identical (Infinite solutions). Different slopes = Intersecting (1 solution).

questions.question: Which of the following is equivalent to <math><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math> for all real numbers <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The expression <math><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math> is a perfect square trinomial. It can be written as <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, which factors as <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, or <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recognizing common factoring patterns like perfect square trinomials (<math><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>±</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>) can save time on the SAT.

questions.question_chart_description: Note: Figure not drawn to scale.
questions.question: In triangle <math><mi>X</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>Z</mi></math>, <math><mi>X</mi><mi>Y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>X</mi><mi>Z</mi></math>. The measure of angle <math><mi>Y</mi></math> is <math><mn>40</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the measure of angle <math><mi>X</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Since <math><mi>X</mi><mi>Y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>X</mi><mi>Z</mi></math>, triangle <math><mi>X</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>Z</mi></math> is isosceles with base <math><mi>Y</mi><mi>Z</mi></math>. Therefore, base angles <math><mi>Y</mi></math> and <math><mi>Z</mi></math> are congruent. So angle <math><mi>Z</mi></math> also measures <math><mn>40</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The sum of angles in a triangle is <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, so angle <math><mi>X</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In an isosceles triangle, the angles opposite the equal sides are equal. Use this property along with the triangle angle sum to find unknown angles.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A recipe for 12 muffins requires 2 cups of flour. At this rate, how many cups of flour are required to make 30 muffins?
questions.explanation: Set up a proportion: <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> cups</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn><mtext> muffins</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext> cups</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>30</mn><mtext> muffins</mtext></mrow></mfrac></math>. Cross-multiply: <math><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>. Divide by 12: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> cups.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For proportional reasoning problems, ensure your units are consistent in the numerator and denominator when setting up ratios.

questions.question: Which of the following numbers is a solution to the inequality <math><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>11</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract 5 from both sides: <math><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Divide by <math><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math> (remember to reverse the inequality): <math><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. The only number in the options less than <math><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math> is <math><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When multiplying or dividing an inequality by a negative number, you must reverse the direction of the inequality sign.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. What is the minimum value of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: The function is quadratic with a positive leading coefficient, so its graph is a parabola opening upward. The minimum occurs at the vertex. The x-coordinate of the vertex is <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Evaluate the function at this point: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. The minimum value is 3.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a quadratic function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, the vertex's x-coordinate is <math><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>/</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. The y-coordinate of the vertex is the minimum (if <math><mi>a</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>) or maximum (if <math><mi>a</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>) value.

questions.question_chart_description: Note: Figure not drawn to scale. In the figure, lines l and m are parallel.
questions.question: In the figure, lines <math><mi>l</mi></math> and <math><mi>m</mi></math> are parallel, and line <math><mi>t</mi></math> is a transversal. If the measure of angle 1 is <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math> and the measure of angle 2 is <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the measure of angle 1?
questions.explanation: Angles 1 and 2 are alternate interior angles, which are congruent when lines are parallel. Therefore, <math><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn></math>. Subtract <math><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi></math>: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></math>. Subtract 10: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn></math>. Divide by 2: <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. Then angle 1 = <math><mn>5</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>110</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Carefully identify the angle relationship (corresponding, alternate interior, same-side interior) based on the figure description. Alternate interior angles are congruent; same-side interior are supplementary.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is a solution to the system of equations below, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></math>? <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math> <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>
questions.explanation: Solve the system. From the second equation, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Substitute into the first equation: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>21</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mn>14</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>28</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. So <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Sometimes you can find the value of an expression like x+y directly by manipulating the equations (e.g., adding or subtracting them) without solving for x and y individually. However, in this case, straightforward solving is efficient.

questions.question: For what positive value of <math><mi>k</mi></math> does the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> have exactly one real solution?
questions.explanation: A quadratic equation has exactly one real solution when its discriminant is zero. The discriminant is <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>64</mn></math>. Set equal to zero: <math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>64</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>64</mn></math> → <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> or <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. Since the question asks for the positive value, <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The discriminant of a quadratic equation <math><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> is <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi></math>. If it's zero, the equation has exactly one real solution (a repeated root).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 200,50' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='95' y='215' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='305' y='215' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='200' y='40' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='150' y='190' font-size='14'>x°</text><text x='250' y='190' font-size='14'>2x°</text><text x='200' y='120' font-size='14'>y°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle ABC with base BC. Angle B is labeled x°, angle C is labeled 2x°, and angle A is labeled y°.
questions.question: In triangle <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown, the measure of angle <math><mi>B</mi></math> is <math><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo></math>, the measure of angle <math><mi>C</mi></math> is <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo></math>, and the measure of angle <math><mi>A</mi></math> is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>°</mo></math>. If <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>30</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The sum of angles in triangle ABC is <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. So, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Substitute <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>30</mn></math>: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Combine like terms: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Subtract 30: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>150</mn></math>. Divide by 5: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 200,50' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='95' y='215' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='305' y='215' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='200' y='40' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='150' y='190' font-size='14'>x°</text><text x='250' y='190' font-size='14'>2x°</text><text x='200' y='120' font-size='14'>y°=2x+30</text><text x='200' y='250' font-size='14' fill='red'>x + 2x + (2x+30) = 180</text><text x='200' y='270' font-size='14' fill='red'>5x + 30 = 180 → x = 30</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Triangle with angles labeled and the equation for the sum of angles shown below.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a geometry problem includes algebraic expressions for angles, use the fundamental relationships (like triangle angle sum) to set up an equation and solve for the variable.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi></math> and <math><mi>b</mi></math> are constants. If <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> and <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Since <math><mi>f</mi></math> is linear, the slope <math><mi>a</mi></math> is constant. <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>19</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>9</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Using point (2,10): <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>. Substitute: <math><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math> → <math><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math> → <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. So <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>28</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a linear function, the slope between any two points is constant. Use two known points to find the slope and y-intercept, then evaluate at the desired x.

questions.question: Which of the following is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> for all <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>3</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Find a common denominator: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Rewrite each fraction: <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></math> and <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></math>. Add the numerators: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. So the sum is <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When adding rational expressions, find a common denominator, combine the numerators, and simplify. Be careful with signs when distributing.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,150 50,250 290,250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 50 230 L 70 230 L 70 250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><text x='35' y='150' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='300' y='260' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='35' y='260' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='30' y='205' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>5</text><text x='170' y='270' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>12</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right triangle ABC with the right angle at C. The vertical side AC has a length of 5. The horizontal side BC has a length of 12.
questions.question: In right triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi></math> is the right angle, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. What is the length of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: By the Pythagorean theorem, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><msup><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><msup><mi>C</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>B</mi><msup><mi>C</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Substituting the given values: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><msup><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>144</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>169</mn></math>. Taking the square root gives <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>169</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,150 50,250 290,250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 50 230 L 70 230 L 70 250' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='35' y='150' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='300' y='260' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='35' y='260' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='150' y='190' font-size='16' fill='red' font-weight='bold' transform='rotate(22.6 150,190)'>AB = 13</text><text x='30' y='205' font-size='14'>5</text><text x='170' y='270' font-size='14'>12</text><text x='200' y='50' font-size='14' fill='blue'>√(5² + 12²) = √169 = 13</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart shows the same right triangle with the hypotenuse AB labeled as 13. A calculation note indicates how the Pythagorean theorem was applied.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize common Pythagorean triples like (5, 12, 13) and (3, 4, 5) to quickly solve right triangle problems without calculation.

questions.question: A store increased the price of a coat by 25%. During a sale, the coat was sold at a 20% discount off the increased price. The sale price of the coat was $240. What was the original price of the coat before the increase?
questions.explanation: Let the original price be <math><mi>P</mi></math>. After a 25% increase, the price becomes <math><mn>1.25</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. A 20% discount on this price means paying 80% of it: <math><mn>0.80</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1.25</mn><mi>P</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.00</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. So the sale price equals the original price. Given the sale price is $240, the original price is $240.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For successive percent changes, remember that a <math><mi>p</mi><mo>%</mo></math> increase followed by a <math><mi>q</mi><mo>%</mo></math> decrease does not cancel out unless <math><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>q</mi></math>. The multiplier is <math><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>p</mi><mn>100</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>q</mi><mn>100</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math>.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></msup></math>. For what value of <math><mi>x</mi></math> does <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve <math><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>. Since <math><mn>32</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></msup></math>, we have <math><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></msup></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For exponential equations, try to rewrite both sides with the same base so you can equate the exponents.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,250 350,250 270,111.4' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='270' y1='111.4' x2='270' y2='250' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><path d='M 270 240 L 280 240 L 280 250' fill='none' stroke='red'/><text x='40' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='355' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='265' y='100' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='275' y='180' font-size='14' fill='red'>h</text><text x='130' y='170' font-size='14'>13</text><text x='320' y='170' font-size='14'>8</text><text x='160' y='270' font-size='14'>11</text><text x='310' y='270' font-size='14'>x</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle ABC with an altitude drawn from vertex A to the base BC. The base is divided into two segments: the segment adjacent to B has length 11, and the segment adjacent to C has length x. The side AB is 13 and side AC is 8.
questions.question: In triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, and the altitude from <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi></math> to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> has length <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>h</mi></math>. If the foot of the altitude divides <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> into segments of lengths <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>11</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> as shown, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
Let the altitude meet BC at point D. The altitude creates two right-angled triangles, ABD and ACD.

1. **In triangle ABD:**
Using the Pythagorean theorem: h2+112=132
h2+121=169
h2=48

2. **In triangle ACD:**
Using the Pythagorean theorem: h2+x2=82
Substitute h2=48 into the equation:
48+x2=64
x2=16
x=4
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,250 350,250 270,111.4' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='270' y1='111.4' x2='270' y2='250' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><text x='40' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='355' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='265' y='100' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='130' y='170' font-size='14'>13</text><text x='320' y='170' font-size='14'>8</text><text x='160' y='270' font-size='14'>11</text><text x='310' y='270' font-size='14' fill='blue' font-weight='bold'>x = 4</text><text x='50' y='50' font-size='14' fill='red'>h² = 13² - 11² = 48</text><text x='220' y='50' font-size='14' fill='blue'>x² = 8² - h² = 64 - 48 = 16</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart visualizes the two-step Pythagorean calculation. First, the altitude squared is found to be 48 using the left triangle. This value is then used in the right triangle to solve for x, which is 4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When an altitude is drawn in a triangle, it creates two right triangles . Use the Pythagorean theorem on both triangles to set up equations relating the segments, altitude, and sides.
